text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

The Examining Officer’s Guide serves as a quick reference guide for Return Preparer Program procedures on examinations. It acts as an index, providing a guide to actions needed for a given examination activity and refers the reader to supporting references.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

SB/SE-04-1014-0039, Interim Guidance on Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) Referrals. SB/SE-04-1115-0074, Reissued Interim Guidance on Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) Referrals. SB/SE-04-0216-0010, Interim Guidance on SB/SE Return Preparer Referrals.
Examination personnel in SBSE and LB&I.

-N, Third Party Contact to Preparers (

) The Return Preparer Program (RPP) is an agency-wide effort to enforce pliance of tax return preparers. Tax return preparers are a critical tax administration and provide a unique opportunity to impact taxpayer behavior and compliance with tax laws. The IRS encourages among tax return preparers through a variety of means by providing enforcement activities to identify and address the most egregious return preparers. The Return Preparer Program includes all tax return not only self-identiﬁed return preparers. All business units under the and Enforcement Organization have tax return preparer strategies, the Return Preparer Office (RPO), the Office of Professional (OPR), Return Integrity Compliance Services (W&I RICS), and
1.2.24.2, Policy Statement 25-2 Return Preparer Misconduct Order SBSE 145.7, Authority to Request and Inspect
The Return Preparer Program (RPP) is an agency
wide effort to enforce com

pliance of tax return preparers. Tax return preparers are a critical component tax administration and provide a unique opportunity to impact taxpayer behavior and compliance with tax laws. The IRS encourages compliance among tax return preparers through a variety of means by providing targeted enforcement activities to identify and address the most egregious return preparers. The Return Preparer Program includes all tax return preparers and not only self

identiﬁed return preparers. All business units under the Services and Enforcement Organization have tax return preparer strategies, including the Return Preparer Office (RPO), the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR), Return Integrity Compliance Services (W&I RICS), and Examination.
4.11.51.2 (09-23-2016) Overview of Return Preparer Program
Examining Officers Guide (

) The Return Preparer Coordinator (RPC) is responsible for planning and nating the implementation of the Area and National Return Preparer RPCs provide direction, knowledge and guidance on tax return preparer related issues. Their duties include: receiving and evaluating referrals regarding potential preparer misconduct, initiating and monitoring Program Action Cases and assisting with and reviewing preparer penalty cases. (

) Examples of when to contact your RPC include, but are not limited to: • A return that appears to have questionable preparation issues • Suspected preparer misconduct • Questionable Power of Attorney • Assistance in obtaining information on a Preparer Tax Identiﬁcation Number (PTIN) • Assistance with completing a preparer referral • Questions about documentation needed to support a preparer • Assistance with establishing and completing a preparer penalty (

) RPCs are the liaison between ﬁeld employees and the Return Preparer Office of Professional Responsibility and IRS Headquarter functions. All questions and concerns should be elevated through the Area RPC. For guidance on Return Preparer Coordinator duties, refer to IRM
, Preparer Program Coordinator. (

) The Return Preparer Program (RPP) allows for the examination of returns prepared by a particular tax return preparer, if information indicates a Return noncompliance. The examination of a tax return preparer’s client’s tax without the approval of the Area Director is prohibited. During the of the noncompliant return preparer, erroneously ﬁled tax returns may be tiﬁed. (

) A tax return preparer is anyone who prepares for compensation or one or more persons to prepare for compensation, any tax return or claim refund. The deﬁnition of a tax return preparer is addressed in CFR
All tax return preparers must properly identify themselves with their Preparer Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number on all tax returns, in which they compensated for preparing. (

) The Return Preparer Coordinator (RPC) and the Area Preparer Steering Committee (PSC) gather information on tax return preparers from various Return sources. This includes: a. Information received from examiners (main source) b. Preparer penalty records c. Information items d. Referrals from other functions See IRM
, PAC Inventory Sources. (

) The RPC maintains ﬁles containing information on return preparer When a pattern of noncompliance is recognized, the IRS will consider prohibit the tax return preparer from practicing before the IRS. Preparer will be limited to cases where information indicates a tax return preparer
4.11 Examining Officers Guide (EOG)
(09-23-2016) Noncompliant Return Preparers

The RPC maintains ﬁles containing information on return preparer activities. When a pattern of noncompliance is recognized, the IRS will consider action to prohibit the tax return preparer from practicing before the IRS. Preparer action will be limited to cases where information indicates a tax return preparer has
engaged in a widespread practice of making material errors. This conduct demonstrates intentional misconduct or clear incompetence in preparing income tax returns. (

) When submitting information about a noncompliant return preparer, be as speciﬁc as possible about noncompliance. Provide as much of the following information as possible: • Identiﬁcation of the tax return preparer • Name and taxpayer identifying number of the examined taxpayer(s) • Examples of the noncompliance • First two pages of the examiner’s report • Source of the information which resulted in a referral • Copies of preparer penalties asserted (
) See IRM
, for submitting referrals about noncompliant preparers. (
) Ghost preparers are preparers who fail to properly identify themselves in ac- cordance with IRC

, Identifying Numbers. All compensated return preparers must have a Preparer Tax Identiﬁcation Number (PTIN). Ghost preparers are deﬁned as preparers who: • Omit any identiﬁcation information and the return appears to be self- prepared • Report a false or fabricated identiﬁcation number on the tax return with the IRS • Report a valid identiﬁcation number, which is assigned to another vidual on the tax return ﬁled with the IRS (
) If an examiner encounters a potential ghost preparer issue during an tion, the following should be considered: • IRC
(b), Failure to Sign Return, and/or IRC
(c), Failure to Furnish Identifying Number • A referral to the RPC (
) The examiner should attempt to obtain as much information about the tax return preparer from the taxpayer as possible in order to support the penalty. (

) The IRS has a voluntary program called the Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) that recognizes the efforts of noncredentialed return preparers who aspire to a higher level of professionalism. Those who participate can meet requirements by obtaining a certain number of continuing education hours in preparation for a speciﬁc tax year. They must also renew their preparer tax identiﬁcation number (PTIN) for the upcoming year and consent to adhere to the obligations in Treasury Department Circular
, Subpart B, Section (
) Participation in the AFSP provides unenrolled return preparers with limited resentation rights. They are permitted to represent taxpayers before the IRS under Rev. Proc.
, which supersedes Rev. Proc.
Unenrolled return preparers are deﬁned in IRM
, Unenrolled Return (
) According to Rev. Proc.
, in order for unenrolled return preparers to represent taxpayers for tax returns ﬁled after December
, they must: Internal Revenue Manual

) The IRS has a voluntary program called the Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) that recognizes the efforts of noncredentialed return preparers who aspire to a higher level of professionalism. Those who participate can meet the requirements by obtaining a certain number of continuing education hours in preparation for a speciﬁc tax year. They must also renew their preparer tax identiﬁcation number (PTIN) for the upcoming year and consent to adhere to the obligations in Treasury Department Circular
, Subpart B, Section
) Participation in the AFSP provides unenrolled return preparers with limited rep- resentation rights. They are permitted to represent taxpayers before the IRS under Rev. Proc.
, which supersedes Rev. Proc.
Unenrolled return preparers are deﬁned in IRM
, Unenrolled Return Preparer. (
) According to Rev. Proc.
, in order for unenrolled return preparers to represent taxpayers for tax returns ﬁled after December

(3) According to Rev. Proc. 2014-42, in order for unenrolled return preparers to represent taxpayers for tax returns ﬁled after December 31, 2015, they must:

• Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the calendar year(s) in which the tax return was ﬁled, and • Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the year(s) in which the representation occurs. Note: For tax returns ﬁled prior to December
, unenrolled return can follow the rules of representation in Rev. Proc.

) Examiners can verify if an unenrolled return preparer holds an AFSP Completion by searching the Directory of Federal Tax Return Preparers Credentials and Select Qualiﬁcations on www.irs.gov rpo.jsf). (

) When the information compiled by the Return Preparer Coordinator (RPC) Preparer Steering Committee (PSC) indicates a pattern of noncompliance exists with the returns prepared, action to prohibit the preparer from before the IRS is considered. (
) Examiners should request a list of all individual and business returns by the preparer under the authority of IRC
, Tax Return Preparer Must Furnish Copy of Return to Taxpayer and Must Retain a Copy or List for opmental purposes during the examination of the preparer penalty case. (

) The RPC orders a sample of returns from these lists as well as the inventory list (PIL) and reviews them for audit potential. If the RPC there is sufficient audit potential in the sample, the RPC will request rence from the PSC. (
) Upon concurrence, the RPC will obtain clearance from the Lead Center (LDC) (IRM
) and CI (IRM
) to ensure that there no conﬂicts with an existing promoter or CI investigation. (

) Upon receipt of LDC and CI clearances, the PSC will submit a program request memorandum to the Area Director through the Territory Manager, approval. If concurrence is not obtained, follow standard conﬂict (

) If approved, the RPC will establish the cases on AIMS using source code and local project and tracking codes. These codes (including source code will be used on all related pick-ups, subsequent and prior years. (
) If not approved, no action will be taken and the tax return preparer project the preparer will be closed. (

) By pursuing preparer penalties when warranted, preparers will be educated proper tax preparation techniques and procedures. Addressing a tax return preparer’s noncompliant behavior will have an impact on the tax returns prepare. Correcting an unlawful tax return preparer can have an impact on the tax compliance of many tax returns. (
) During an examination of the client taxpayer’s return, do not disclose a preparer penalty decision to the taxpayer or preparer. (
) The examination case of the related client should be closed prior to ing the preparer penalty case.
Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the calendar year(s) in which the tax return was ﬁled, and Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the year(s) in which the representation occurs.
Note: For tax returns ﬁled prior to December 31, 2015, unenrolled return preparers can follow the rules of representation in Rev. Proc. 81-38.
(09-23-2016) Initiating a Preparer Project
(09-23-2016) Preparer Penalties Overview
Program
) Consideration of tax return preparer penalties under IRC
and IRC required on all examinations. (

) Examination employees should consider compliance of the tax return during every examination. SB/SE and LB&I examination employees address noncompliance of return preparers through proposed preparer penalties and referrals to the Area’s RPC. Examination employees should not send to Return Preparer Office (RPO) to address noncompliant return preparers lieu of penalty consideration. Some common examples of noncompliance should have penalty considerations and a referral to the Area’s RPC • PTIN requirement violations • Egregious errors and/or omissions on client tax returns, and • A pattern of noncompliance by the tax return preparer (
) If a tax return preparer is not tax compliant, the examination employee discuss the potential for a tax return preparer information referral with the group manager and Area RPC. (
) Examiners can ﬁnd information on IRC
, Understatement of Liability by Tax Return Preparer in IRM
, Preparer, Promoter, Material Advisor Penalties. • IRC
(a), Understatement Due to Unreasonable Position • IRC
(b), Understatement Due to Willful or Reckless Conduct (
) A mandatory referral to the OPR is required when IRC
(b) penalties asserted. (
) IRC
, Other Assessable Penalties With Respect to the Preparation of Returns for Other Persons. See IRM
, IRC
Penalties That May Apply to a Tax Return Preparer, for detailed information regarding IRC
penalties. (
) IRC
penalties can be asserted in conjunction with IRC
penalties. (
) Anyone who is paid to prepare or assist in the preparation of a tax must obtain a Preparer Tax Identiﬁcation Number (PTIN) per CFR

)(ii). A PTIN cannot be shared among multiple individuals in a ﬁrm – each person must obtain and use their own PTIN. The PTIN must be in the tax return preparer section of the tax return ﬁled with the IRS. If the PTIN is not present on the return prepared then the tax return preparer is subject to an IRC
(c), Failure to Furnish Identifying Number , penalty. PTIN must be nine (
) characters beginning with a ‘P’. Anything else is not ceptable and is subject to IRC
(c) penalty. (
) Examiners may ﬁnd more information on preparer penalties at IRM
, Penalty Handbook, Preparer, Promoter, Material Advisor Penalties. (
) IRC

, Rules for Application of Assessable Penalties, treats preparer penalties as taxes. Therefore, when an examiner makes contact to the preparer/promoter is liable for a penalty, third party notiﬁcation may be required. Internal Revenue Manual

Examination employees should consider compliance of the tax return preparer during every examination. SB/SE and LB&I examination employees address noncompliance of return preparers through proposed preparer penalties and referrals to the Area’s RPC. Examination employees should not send referrals to Return Preparer Office (RPO) to address noncompliant return preparers in lieu of penalty consideration. Some common examples of noncompliance that should have penalty considerations and a referral to the Area’s RPC include:
IRC 6694(a), Understatement Due to Unreasonable Position IRC 6694(b), Understatement Due to Willful or Reckless Conduct
Examiners may ﬁnd more information on preparer penalties at IRM 20.1.6, Penalty Handbook, Preparer, Promoter, Material Advisor Penalties.
IRC

, Rules for Application of Assessable Penalties, treats preparer penalties as taxes. Therefore, when an examiner makes contact to determine if the preparer/promoter is liable for a penalty, third party notiﬁcation may be required.
4.11 Examining Officers Guide (EOG)
) Third-party contact deﬁned. Contacts subject to IRC
(c), and this regula- tion shall be called “third-party contacts.” A third-party contact is a communication which —
) Is initiated by an IRS employee;
) Is made to a person other than the taxpayer;
) Is made with respect to the determination or collection of the tax liability of such taxpayer;
) Discloses the identity of the taxpayer being investigated; and
) Discloses the association of the IRS employee with the IRS. (

) If the examination of a preparer’s client’s tax returns are completed for the purpose of determining whether the preparer is subject to a preparer penalty AND if the ﬁve requirements found in the deﬁnition of CFR

(b) are met, third party contact procedures must be followed. Note: In order to adhere to third party contact procedures, examiners should advise taxpayers they were selected for audit as part of a preparer compli- ance review and ask if the taxpayer fears reprisal. Examiners should not disclose any more information than is necessary to conduct the of the client taxpayer. (
) Contacts subject to IRC
(c) and this regulation shall be called contacts. A third-party contact is a communication which—
Is initiated by an IRS employee;
Is made to a person other than the taxpayer;
Is made with respect to the determination or collection of the tax liability of such taxpayer;
Discloses the identity of the taxpayer being investigated; and
Discloses the association of the IRS employee with the IRS. (
) In every third party contact (IRM

,) the examiner must advise the third party contact (including client taxpayer) before the conclusion of the initial interview that by law the IRS is required to provide his or her name to the preparer/taxpayer as a third party contact (IRM

). There is an exception to this notiﬁcation if the third party believes that notifying the taxpayer may result in reprisal against them or any person. The examiner should accept the third party’s response on face value. In addition, the examiner may make the reprisal determination based on the facts and stances of the case. (
) If any reprisal concerns exist, the examiner will complete Form
, Third Party Contact Report Form, with only the information in IRM
Form
is forwarded to the Area Third Party Contact Coordinator. The in- formation on Form
is retained in a database, but will not be included in the list of persons contacted (Letter

,) when provided to the taxpayer. Caution: Ensure information about an individual fearing reprisal is not disclosed. Information in the case ﬁle referencing the identity of the third party should be placed in a conﬁdential envelope and clearly marked. (
) If the preparer’s/promoter’s clients are being contacted to start an of the client’s return, then this is not considered a third party contact since
If the preparer’s/promoter’s clients are being contacted to start an examination of the client’s return, then this is not considered a third party contact since the
purpose of the contact is to determine the client’s tax liability and not whether the preparer/promoter is subject to a penalty. This is an example of a non-PAC audit.

Example: If during a compliance review of a preparer’s EITC ﬁles it is discovered that a client’s return appears to have overstated EITC, the contact with the client is NOT considered a third party contact.
) Refer to IRM
, Third-Party Notiﬁcation in PACs, for additional informa- tion. (
) Refer to IRM
, Program Action Cases Overview, for information on PACs.
Refer to IRM 4.1.10.5, Third-Party Notiﬁcation in PACs, for additional informa-
Note: Caution should be taken to not disclose any tax information of a conﬁdential nature when contacts are made with third parties (IRM 4.10.3.3.1.4(3)).

IRC 6103(k)(6),provides that Service employees may make investiga- tive disclosures to the extent necessary in obtaining information, which is not otherwise reasonably available, with respect to the correct deter- mination of tax, liability for tax, or the amount to be collected. See IRM 11.3.21.3, Requirements for Investigative Disclosures, for additional guidance.
This section provides guidance on preparing and submitting return preparer referrals.
) When appropriate, SB/SE examiners will make a referral to their Area RPC on Form
, Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Return Preparer Referral. Form
should be forwarded via e-mail to the Area RPC where the practi- tioner resides. The e-mail address for your Area RPC can be found on Form

) When appropriate, LB&I examiners will e–mail the LB&I RPC explaining the reason for the referral, including the tax return preparer’s name, address, and identiﬁcation number, the taxpayer’s name and identiﬁcation number, and an explanation of the noncompliance identiﬁed on the part of the tax return preparer. (
) Examination employees should also adhere to procedures for making other types of tax return preparer referrals per IRM
, Examination Officers Guide (EOG), Power of Attorney Rights and Responsibilities. Examiners may contact their Area’s RPC for guidance on making referrals.
Examining Officers Guide (
) SB/SE and LB&I examination employees should not send referrals to the in lieu of penalty consideration. (
) The public and IRS non-enforcement employees may send a referral to RPO using Form

, , Return Preparer Complaint, for suspected misconduct. Based on speciﬁc criteria, the RPO will forward the referral to the Exam Area Return Preparer Coordinator (RPC) for consideration. RPO generally does not send a referral to the RPC until RPO receives at least three or more com- plaints against a tax return preparer, unless the tax return preparer is under examination. Form
has instructions on when to use the form and when to send a referral to RPO. Form
may be submitted through the RPO e-mail box at *RPO Referrals. (

) The Office of Professional Responsibility supports the IRS’s strategy to enhance enforcement of the tax law by ensuring that tax professionals adhere to tax practice standards and follow the law. OPR is the governing body re- sponsible for interpreting and applying the Regulations Governing Practice before the Internal Revenue Service (Circular
) OPR addresses behavior that is willful, reckless or incompetent. OPR’s mission is to educate and reach out to people who practice before the IRS who are subject to Circular

OPR has jurisdiction over practice by attorneys, certiﬁed public accountants, enrolled agents, enrolled actuaries and appraisers. OPR does not regulate unenrolled preparers. Any matters of mis- conduct on the part of an unenrolled preparer should be referred to the local RPC for consideration and resolution. (

) SB/SE and LB&I employees should send referrals to the OPR for disreputable conduct and incompetence involving attorneys, certiﬁed public accountants, enrolled agents, enrolled actuaries and appraisers. Examples of misconduct under Circular
that may warrant a referral to OPR are found at IRM
, Referrals to the Office of Professional Responsibility. SB/SE employees may send referrals to OPR after they take Title
enforcement actions (preparer penalties). Detailed information on referrals to OPR may be found in IRM
, Referrals to the Office of Professional Responsibility, and IRM
, Referral to the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR). Examiners should review IRM
and may consult with the Area Return Preparer Coordinator (RPC) when making OPR referrals. Note: Send a copy of the referral for informational purposes to your Area’s RPC.
(09-23-2016) Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) Referrals
Note: Send a copy of the referral for informational purposes to your Area’s RPC.
Note: RPCs do NOT need to approve referrals to OPR.
Note: RPCs do NOT need to approve referrals to
Form
, Suspected Practitioner Misconduct Report for the Office of Profes- sional Responsibility, is the form used to make a referral to OPR. Managerial approval of Form
is not required. OPR will provide guidance and feedback to ﬁeld/agency sources regarding essential referral criteria for each relevant Circular
provision.
Note: IRC 6694(b) penalties are mandatory referrals to OPR.
For IRC 6694(b), these mandatory referrals are made to OPR in matters where preparer penalties are asserted when there is willful or reckless conduct.
page (
) The OPR web site has a searchable database containing the names of all individuals currently under suspension or disbarment. (
) Form
, Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) Referral, is used for referrals from OPR to SB/SE and LB&I. (
) The Examiner will take the following steps when they receive a Form
referral case from OPR: Within
days of receipt from OPR, the examiner complete Part V of Form
and return it to the OPR then take the following actions. If the referral is surveyed, complete the following: • Form
, Income Tax Survey After Assignment , with managerial currence, • Notify OPR of Survey. Forward Form
and a copy of Form
OPR, • Close case ﬁle. If an examination is conducted: • Complete Part III of Form
, • Return Form
to OPR prior to the case closing from the group. (

) The SB/SE Lead Development Center (LDC): • receives, identiﬁes and develops leads on individuals and entities that promote or aid in the promotion of abusive tax schemes and/or tax return preparers, • authorizes civil investigations when necessary, • evaluates and develops information from internal and external The LDC is responsible for the approval of all SB/SE IRC

and IRC investigations of promoters/preparers. The LDC coordinates with Criminal In- vestigation, Counsel and the Department of Justice (DOJ) to ensure that appropriate penalties and/or sanctions are pursued when warranted, and provides ﬁeld support for ongoing investigations. (

) The LDC authorizes investigations into potentially abusive tax return as well as promoters of abusive tax schemes. Authorized investigations are assigned to specially trained examiners through the Abusive Transaction Issues Area PSP Coordinator. A deﬁnition of abusive transactions can be in IRM
, Abusive Transactions Deﬁned. (
) To report suspected promoters of illegal tax schemes or abusive tax return preparers, e-mail a completed Form

, Report Suspected Abusive Tax Promotions or Preparers, as well as any available documentation regarding promotion or activity to *LDC. You can also mail or fax the information to: IRS Lead Development Center Stop MS
Avila Road Laguna Niguel, CA
Fax:

The SB/SE Lead Development Center (LDC): • receives, identiﬁes and develops leads on individuals and entities that promote or aid in the promotion of abusive tax schemes and/or tax return preparers, • authorizes civil investigations when necessary, • evaluates and develops information from internal and external The LDC is responsible for the approval of all SB/SE IRC

and IRC investigations of promoters/preparers. The LDC coordinates with Criminal In- vestigation, Counsel and the Department of Justice (DOJ) to ensure that appropriate penalties and/or sanctions are pursued when warranted, and provides ﬁeld support for ongoing investigations. The LDC authorizes investigations into potentially abusive tax return as well as promoters of abusive tax schemes. Authorized investigations are assigned to specially trained examiners through the Abusive Transaction Issues Area PSP Coordinator. A deﬁnition of abusive transactions can be in IRM

) If a tax return preparer fraud referral to Criminal Investigations is contact your local Return Preparer Coordinator (RPC) and Fraud Technical Advisor (FTA) to discuss the suspected return preparer fraud. (
) Some examples of return preparer fraud include: • Inﬂating income, deductions, credits, or withholding without the er’s knowledge • Diverting refunds into the bank account of the return preparer (
) Referrals to Criminal Investigation (CI) can be made on Form

, Referral Report of Potential Criminal Fraud Cases. Examiners should develop the to establish ﬁrm indicators of fraud/willfulness, including, but not limited to: • A description of the ﬁrm indications/ willfulness • Taxpayer’s explanation of the ﬁrm indications/ willfulness • The estimated criminal liability (
) If the criminal referral is declined, or if the criminal case is resolved, should retain a copy of the related taxpayer’s report (Form
) and workpapers so the IRC
civil return preparer penalties may be See IRM
, Return Preparers, IRM
, Return Preparer Fraud, IRM
, Return Preparer Misconduct Program, and Return Preparer Mis- conduct , for additional information. (
) Examiners should be alert to unscrupulous tax return preparers. tax return preparers may alter tax data and/or misdirect a portion or all of a refund. The IRS has established a Policy Statement (P
) per IRM Servicewide Policies and Authorities - Policy Statements for Special Topics, that covers procedures for victims of tax return preparer misconduct. (

) If an examiner is made aware of tax return preparer misconduct by a they will take actions to correct the taxpayer’s account. Please see IRM Return Preparer Misconduct Program, for more information. (
) See IRM
, Examining Officers Guide (EOG), Power of Attorney and Responsibilities, for uniform guidance to employees who interact with resentatives and/or who receive and inspect Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative (POA), Form
, Tax Information zation (TIA), and similar documents.

Referrals to Criminal Investigation (CI) can be made on Form 2797, Referral Report of Potential Criminal Fraud Cases. Examiners should develop the issue to establish ﬁrm indicators of fraud/willfulness, including, but not limited to:
(09-23-2016) Return Preparer Misconduct

If an examiner is made aware of tax return preparer misconduct by a taxpayer, they will take actions to correct the taxpayer’s account. Please see IRM 25.24, Return Preparer Misconduct Program, for more information.
